description:
Arripis georgiana, commonly known as the Australian herring or Tommy ruff, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Arripidae. It is found in coastal waters along the southern coast of Australia, from Geraldton in Western Australia to Corner Inlet in Victoria.

The Australian herring is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths of 25-35 cm. It has an elongated, streamlined body with a large, slightly protruding mouth. The dorsal fin is composed of two parts, with the first part having 8-9 spines and the second part having 10-11 soft rays. The anal fin has 3 spines and 9-10 soft rays. The scales are small and cycloid in shape.

Arripis georgiana is an important commercial and recreational fishing species in Australia. It is often caught using a variety of methods, including hook and line, beach seine nets, and offshore trawling. The Australian herring is also an important prey species for larger predatory fish, seabirds, and marine mammals in the coastal ecosystems it inhabits.
